sentences.translated: Under torture, you say not only what the inquisitor wants, but also what you imagine might please him, because a bond (this one, truly diabolical) is established between you and him... I know these things, Ubertino, I was also part of those groups of men who believe they produce truth with red-hot iron.

sentences.original: Ebbene, sappi, l'incandescenza della verità è di altra fiamma.
sentences.translated: Indeed, know this, the incandescence of truth is of another flame.

sentences.original: Sotto tortura Bentivenga può avere detto le menzogne più assurde, perché non parlava più lui, ma la sua lussuria, i demoni dell'anima sua.
sentences.translated: Under torture, Bentivenga may have told the most absurd lies, because it was no longer he who was speaking, but his lust, the demons of his soul.

sentences.original:
"

sentences.original:
"

sentences.translated: "Yes, there is a lust for pain, just as there is a lust for adoration and even a lust for humility."

sentences.original: Se bastò così poco agli angeli ribelli per mutare il loro ardore d'adorazione e umiltà in ardore di superbia e di rivolta, cosa dire di un essere umano?
sentences.translated: If it took so little for the rebellious angels to change their ardor of adoration and humility into ardor of pride and revolt, what about a human being?

sentences.original: Ecco, ora lo sai, fu questo pensiero che mi colse nel corso delle mie inquisizioni.
sentences.translated: Here it is, now you know, it was this thought that struck me during the course of my investigations.

sentences.original: E fu per questo che rinunciai a quella attività.
sentences.translated: And that is why I gave up that activity.

sentences.original: Mi mancò il coraggio di inquisire sulle debolezze dei malvagi, perché scoprii che sono le stesse debolezze dei santi.
sentences.translated: I lacked the courage to inquire into the weaknesses of the wicked, because I discovered that they are the same weaknesses as those of the saints.

sentences.translated: Ubertino had listened to Guglielmo's last words as if he did not understand what he was saying.

sentences.original: Dall'espressione del suo volto, sempre più ispirata ad affettuosa commiserazione, capii che egli riteneva Guglielmo preda di sentimenti molto colpevoli, che egli perdonava perché molto lo amava.
sentences.translated: From the expression on his face, increasingly inspired by affectionate commiseration, I understood that he considered William prey to very guilty feelings, which he forgave because he loved him very much.

sentences.translated: One must fight temptations.

sentences.translated: However, I missed your support, and we could have dismantled that bad gang.

sentences.translated: And instead, you know what happened, I myself was accused of being too weak with them, and I was suspected of heresy.

sentences.original: Sei stato troppo debole anche tu, nel combattere il male.
sentences.translated: You were too weak as well, in fighting evil.

sentences.translated: It will never cease, this condemnation, this shadow, this mire that prevents us from touching the source?

sentences.original: " Si appressò ancora più a Guglielmo, come se fosse timoroso che qualcuno lo udisse:
sentences.translated: He drew even closer to William, as if he was afraid that someone might hear him:

sentences.original: "Anche qui, anche tra queste mura consacrate alla preghiera, lo sai?
sentences.translated: Even here, even within these walls consecrated to prayer, you know?

sentences.translated: Let your heart speak, question the faces, do not listen to the tongues... Come now, why must we speak of these sorrows and frighten this young friend of ours?

sentences.translated: Then I met Marsilio, his ideas on the empire, the people, a new law for the kingdoms of the earth attracted me, and so I ended up in that group of our brethren who are advising the emperor.

sentences.translated: "Oh Lord, into whose hands has your church fallen!" He turned his head towards the altar.

sentences.translated: Transformed into a prostitute, softened by luxury, she writhes in lust like a snake in heat!

sentences.translated: From the naked purity of the Bethlehem stable, wood as wood was the lignum vitae of the cross, to the golden and stone bacchanals, look, even here, you have seen the portal, one cannot escape the pride of images!

sentences.translated: "At last, the days of the Antichrist are near, and I am afraid, William!" He looked around, fixing his wide-eyed gaze within the dark naves, as if the Antichrist were about to appear at any moment, and I truly expected to see him.

sentences.original: "I suoi luogotenenti sono già qui, mandati come Cristo mandò gli apostoli per il mondo!
sentences.translated: His lieutenants are already here, sent as Christ sent the apostles into the world!

sentences.original: Stanno conculcando la Città di Dio, seducono con l'inganno, l'ipocrisia e la violenza.
sentences.translated: They are trampling the City of God, seducing with deceit, hypocrisy, and violence.

sentences.original:
Sarà allora che Dio dovrà mandare i suoi servi, Elia ed Enoch, che egli ha conservato ancora in vita nel paradiso terrestre perché un giorno confondano l'Anticristo, e verranno a profetare vestiti di sacco, e predicheranno la penitenza con l'esempio e con la parola..."
"Sono già venuti, Ubertino," disse Guglielmo, mostrando il suo saio di francescano.
sentences.translated:
It will then be that God will send his servants, Elijah and Enoch, whom he has kept alive in the terrestrial paradise so that one day they may confound the Antichrist, and they will come to prophesy dressed in sackcloth, and will preach penance with example and with word...

"They have already come, Ubertino," said William, showing his Franciscan habit.

sentences.original: "Ma non hanno ancora vinto, è il momento che l'Anticristo, pieno di furore, comanderà di uccidere Enoch ed Elia e i loro corpi perché ognuno possa vederli e tema di volerli imitare.
sentences.translated: But they have not yet won, it is the moment when the Antichrist, full of fury, will command to kill Enoch and Elijah and their bodies so that everyone can see them and fear to want to imitate them.

sentences.original:
Così come volevano uccidere me..."

sentences.translated:
So, just as they wanted to kill me...

At that moment, terrified, I thought that Ubertino was in the grip of some kind of divine madness, and I feared for his sanity.

sentences.original: Ora a distanza di tempo, sapendo quel che so, e cioè che qualche anno dopo fu misteriosamente ucciso in una città tedesca, e mai non si seppe da chi, sono più atterrito ancora, perché evidentemente quella sera Ubertino profetava.
sentences.translated: Now that some time has passed, knowing what I know, that is, that a few years later he was mysteriously killed in a German city, and it was never known by whom, I am even more terrified, because evidently that evening Ubertino was prophesying.

sentences.original: "Lo sai, l'abate Gioacchino aveva detto la verità.
sentences.translated: You know, Abbot Joachim had told the truth.

sentences.original: Siamo giunti alla sesta era della storia umana, in cui appariranno due Anticristi, l'Anticristo mistico e l'Anticristo proprio, questo accade ora nella sesta epoca, dopo che è apparso Francesco a configurare nella sua stessa carne le cinque piaghe di Gesù Crocifisso.
sentences.translated: We have reached the sixth era of human history, in which two Antichrists will appear, the mystical Antichrist and the proper Antichrist. This is happening now in the sixth epoch, after Francis appeared to configure in his own flesh the five wounds of Jesus Crucified.

sentences.original: Bonifacio fu l'Anticristo mistico, e l'abdicazione di Celestino non fu valida, Bonifacio fu la bestia che viene dal mare le cui sette teste rappresentano le offese ai peccati capitali e le dieci corna le offese ai comandamenti, e i cardinali che lo attorniavano erano le locuste, il cui corpo è Appolyon!
sentences.translated: Boniface was the mystical Antichrist, and Celestine's abdication was not valid. Boniface was the beast that comes from the sea, whose seven heads represent the offenses against the capital sins and the ten horns the offenses against the commandments, and the cardinals who surrounded him were the locusts, whose body is Appolyon!

sentences.original: Ma il numero della bestia, se ne leggi il nome in lettere greche, è Benedicti!" Mi fissò per vedere se avevo capito e alzò un dito ammonendomi.
sentences.translated: "But the number of the beast, if you read its name in Greek letters, is Benedicti!" He stared at me to see if I had understood and raised a finger, admonishing me.

sentences.original: "Benedetto XI fu l'Anticristo proprio, la bestia che ascende dalla terra!
sentences.translated: Blessed XI was the Antichrist himself, the beast that ascends from the earth!

sentences.original: Dio ha permesso che tale mostro di vizio e di iniquità governasse la sua chiesa
sentences.translated: God allowed such a monster of vice and iniquity to govern his church.

sentences.original: perché le virtù del suo successore sfolgorassero di gloria!"
sentences.translated: "so that the virtues of his successor might shine with glory!"

"Ma padre santo," obbiettai con un filo di voce, facendomi coraggio, "il suo successore è Giovanni!"

Ubertino si posò una mano sulla fronte come per cancellare un sogno molesto.
sentences.translated:
"But holy father," I objected in a low voice, gathering my courage, "his successor is John!"

Ubertino placed a hand on his forehead as if to erase a troublesome dream.

sentences.original: Respirava a fatica, era stanco.
sentences.translated: He was breathing with difficulty, he was tired.

sentences.original: "Già.
sentences.translated: Already.

sentences.translated: The calculations were wrong, we are still waiting for the angelic pope... But meanwhile, Francis and Dominic have appeared.

sentences.original: " Alzò gli occhi al cielo e disse come pregando (ma fui sicuro che stava recitando una pagina del suo grande libro sull'albero della vita):
sentences.translated: He raised his eyes to the sky and said as if praying (but I was sure he was reciting a page from his great book on the tree of life):

sentences.original: "Quorum primus seraphico calculo purgatus et ardore celico inflammatus totum incendere videbatur.
sentences.translated: "Of whom the first, purified by seraphic calculation and inflamed by celestial ardor, seemed to set everything on fire."

sentences.original: Secundus vero verbo predicationis fecundus super mundi tenebras clarius radiavit... Sì, se queste sono state le promesse, il papa angelico dovrà venire.
sentences.translated: Second, indeed, the word of the proclamation shone more fruitful over the world's darkness... Yes, if these have been the promises, the angelic pope must come.

sentences.original:

sentences.translated: Meanwhile, I am here to prevent the human emperor from being expelled.

"Your angelic father was also spoken of by Brother Dolcino..."
"Do not utter that snake's name again!" Ubertino shouted, and for the first time I saw him transform, from being distressed, into being angry.

sentences.translated: He has defiled the word of Gioacchino of Calabria and made it a source of death and filth!

sentences.original: Messaggero dell'Anticristo, se mai ve ne furono.
sentences.translated: Messenger of the Antichrist, if ever there were any.

sentences.original: Ma tu Guglielmo parli così perché in verità non credi all'avvento dell'Anticristo e i tuoi maestri di Oxford ti hanno insegnato a idolatrare la ragione inaridendo le capacità profetiche del tuo cuore!
sentences.translated: But you, William, speak thus because in truth you do not believe in the coming of the Antichrist, and your masters at Oxford have taught you to idolize reason, drying up the prophetic abilities of your heart!

sentences.original:
"
"Ti sbagli Ubertino," rispose con molta serietà Guglielmo.
sentences.translated: "You are mistaken, Ubertino," replied Guglielmo very seriously.

sentences.original:
"Tu sai che venero più di ogni altro tra i miei maestri Ruggiero Bacone..."
"Che vaneggiava di macchine volanti, " motteggiò amaramente Ubertino.
sentences.translated:
"You know that I honor more than any other among my masters Roger Bacon..."
"Who rambled on about flying machines," Ubertino mocked bitterly.

sentences.original: "Che ha parlato chiaramente e limpidamente sull'Anticristo, ne ha avvertito i segni nella corruzione del mondo e nell'indebolimento della sapienza.
sentences.translated: Who has spoken clearly and lucidly about the Antichrist, has warned of its signs in the corruption of the world and the weakening of wisdom.

sentences.original: Ma ha insegnato che vi è un solo modo per prepararci alla sua venuta:
sentences.translated: But he taught that there is only one way to prepare ourselves for his coming:

sentences.original: studiare i segreti della natura, usare del sapere per migliorare il genere umano.
sentences.translated: To study the secrets of nature, to use knowledge to improve humankind.

sentences.original: Puoi prepararti a combattere l'Anticristo studiando le virtù curative delle erbe, la natura delle pietre, e persino progettando le macchine volanti di cui sorridi.
sentences.translated: You can prepare yourself to fight the Antichrist by studying the healing virtues of herbs, the nature of stones, and even by designing the flying machines you smile at.

sentences.original:
"
"L'Anticristo del tuo Bacone era un pretesto per coltivare l'orgoglio della ragione.
sentences.translated: "The Antichrist of your Bacon was a pretext to cultivate the pride of reason."

sentences.original:
"
"Santo pretesto.
sentences.translated: "Holy pretext."

sentences.original:
"
"Nulla che sia pretestuoso è santo.
sentences.translated: "Nothing that is pretentious is holy."

sentences.original: Guglielmo, sai che ti voglio bene.
sentences.translated: William, you know I love you.

sentences.original: Sai che confido molto in te.
sentences.translated: You know that I trust you a lot.

sentences.original: Castiga la tua intelligenza, impara a piangere sulle piaghe del Signore, butta via i tuoi libri.
sentences.translated: Punish your intelligence, learn to weep over the wounds of the Lord, throw away your books.

sentences.original:
"
"Tratterrò soltanto il tuo," sorrise Guglielmo.
sentences.translated: "Only yours will I keep," smiled William.

sentences.original: Ubertino sorrise anch'egli e lo minacciò col dito:
sentences.translated: Ubertino also smiled and threatened him with his finger:

sentences.original: "Sciocco di un inglese.
sentences.translated: Fool of an Englishman.

sentences.original: E non ridere troppo dei tuoi simili.
sentences.translated: And do not laugh too much at your peers.

sentences.original: Anzi, quelli che non puoi amare, temili.
sentences.translated: On the contrary, those whom you cannot love, you fear.

sentences.original: E guardati dall'abbazia.
sentences.translated: And beware of the abbey.

sentences.original: Questo luogo non mi piace.
sentences.translated: This place does not appeal to me.

sentences.original:
"
"Voglio appunto conoscerlo meglio," disse Guglielmo congedandosi, "andiamo Adso.
sentences.translated: "I want to get to know him better," said William as he took his leave, "let's go Adso."

sentences.original:
"
"Io ti dico che non è buono, e tu dici che vuoi conoscerlo.
sentences.translated: "I tell you that he is not good, and you say that you want to meet him."

sentences.original:
Ah!" disse Ubertino scuotendo la testa.
"A proposito," disse ancora Guglielmo già a metà della navata, "chi è quel monaco che sembra un animale e parla la lingua di Babele?
sentences.translated:
"Ah!" said Ubertino, shaking his head.
"By the way," said William, already halfway down the nave, "who is that monk who looks like an animal and speaks the language of Babel?"

sentences.original: "Salvatore?
sentences.translated: Salvatore?

sentences.original: " si voltò Ubertino che già si era inginocchiato.
sentences.translated: Ubertino, who had already knelt, turned around.

sentences.original: "Credo di averne fatto dono io a questa abbazia... Insieme al cellario.
sentences.translated: I believe I gave it to this abbey... Along with the cellarer.

sentences.original: Quando lasciai il saio francescano tornai per qualche tempo nel mio vecchio convento a Casale, e lì trovai altri frati in angustie, perché la comunità li accusava di essere spirituali della mia setta... così si esprimevano.
sentences.translated: When I left the Franciscan habit, I returned for some time to my old convent in Casale, and there I found other friars in distress, because the community accused them of being spirituals of my sect... that's how they expressed it.

sentences.original: Mi adoperai in loro favore, ottenendo che potessero seguire il mio esempio.
sentences.translated: I will work in their favor, obtaining that they could follow my example.

sentences.original: E due, Salvatore e Remigio, ne ho trovati proprio qui, quando vi arrivai l'anno scorso.
sentences.translated: It's two, Salvatore and Remigio, I found them right here when I arrived last year.

sentences.original: Salvatore...
sentences.translated: Salvatore...

sentences.original: Davvero, pare una bestia.
sentences.translated: Really, it seems like a beast.

sentences.original: Ma è servizievole.
sentences.translated: But it is helpful.

sentences.original:
"

Guglielmo esitò un istante.
sentences.translated: William hesitated for a moment.

sentences.original: "L'ho sentito dire penitenziagite.
sentences.translated: I heard him say "penitenziagite."

sentences.original:
"
Ubertino tacque.
sentences.translated: Ubertino fell silent.

sentences.original: Mosse una mano come per scacciare un pensiero molesto.
sentences.translated: He moved a hand as if to shoo away a bothersome thought.

sentences.original: "No, non credo.
sentences.translated: No, I don't think so.

sentences.original: Sai come sono questi fratelli laici.
sentences.translated: You know how these lay brothers are.

sentences.original: Gente di campagna, che hanno udito forse qualche predicatore vagante, e non sanno cosa si dicono.
sentences.translated: People from the countryside, who have perhaps heard some wandering preacher, and do not know what they are saying.

sentences.original: A Salvatore avrei altro da rimproverare, è una bestia ghiotta e lussuriosa.
sentences.translated: To Salvatore, I would have other things to reproach, he is a gluttonous and lustful beast.

sentences.original: Ma nulla, nulla contro l'ortodossia.
sentences.translated: But nothing, nothing against orthodoxy.

sentences.original: No, il male dell'abbazia è un altro, cercalo in chi sa troppo, non in chi non sa nulla.
sentences.translated: No, the evil of the abbey is another, seek it in those who know too much, not in those who know nothing.

sentences.original: Non costruire un castello di sospetti su una parola.
sentences.translated: Don't build a castle of suspicions on a single word.

sentences.original:
"
"Non lo farei mai," rispose Guglielmo.
sentences.translated: "I would never do that," replied William.

sentences.original: "Ho smesso di fare l'inquisitore proprio per non fare questo.
sentences.translated: I stopped being an inquisitor precisely to avoid doing this.

sentences.original: Però mi piace ascoltare anche le parole, e poi ci penso su.
sentences.translated: But I also like to listen to the words, and then I think about them.

sentences.original:
"
"Tu pensi troppo.
sentences.translated: "You think too much."

sentences.original: Ragazzo," disse rivolgendosi a me, "non trarre troppi cattivi esempi dal tuo maestro.
sentences.translated: "Boy," he said, turning to me, "do not draw too many bad examples from your teacher."

sentences.original: L'unica cosa a cui si deve pensare, e me ne rendo conto alla fine della mia vita, è la morte.
sentences.translated: The only thing one should think about, and I realize this at the end of my life, is death.

sentences.original: Mors est quies viatoris - finis est omnis laboris.
sentences.translated: Death is the traveler's rest - the end of all labor.

sentences.original: Lasciatemi pregare.
sentences.translated: Let me pray.

sentences.original:
# Primo giorno 

##
sentences.translated: # First day

sentences.original:
Verso nona

Dove Guglielmo ha un dialogo dottissimo con
Severino erborista

Ripercorremmo la navata centrale e uscimmo dal portale da cui eravamo entrati.
sentences.translated:
Toward the ninth hour

Where William has a very learned dialogue with
Severinus the herbalist

We retraced the central nave and exited through the portal by which we had entered.

sentences.original: Avevo ancora le parole di Ubertino, tutte, che mi ronzavano nella testa.
sentences.translated: I still had all of Ubertino's words buzzing around in my head.

sentences.original: "E' un uomo... strano," ardii dire a Guglielmo.
sentences.translated: "It's a strange man," I dared to say to William.

sentences.original: "E', o è stato, per molti aspetti, un grande uomo.
sentences.translated: It's, or it was, in many respects, a great man.

sentences.original: Ma proprio per questo è strano.
sentences.translated: But precisely for this reason it is strange.

sentences.original: Sono solo gli uomini piccoli che sembrano normali.
sentences.translated: Only small men seem normal.

sentences.original: Ubertino avrebbe potuto diventare uno degli eretici che ha contribuito a fare bruciare, o un cardinale di santa romana chiesa.
sentences.translated: Ubertino could have become one of the heretics that he contributed to burning, or a cardinal of the holy Roman church.

sentences.original: E' andato vicinissimo a entrambe le perversioni.
sentences.translated: He came very close to both perversions.

sentences.original: Quando parlo con Ubertino ho l'impressione che l'inferno sia il paradiso guardato dall'altra parte.
sentences.translated: When I speak with Ubertino, I get the impression that hell is paradise seen from the other side.

sentences.original:
"

Non capii cosa volesse dire:
sentences.translated: I did not understand what it meant:

sentences.original: "Da che parte?" domandai.
sentences.translated: "Which side?" I asked.

sentences.original: "Eh già," ammise Guglielmo, "si tratta di sapere se ci sono delle parti e se c'è un tutto.
sentences.translated: "Indeed," admitted William, "it's a matter of knowing if there are parts and if there is a whole."

sentences.original: Ma non darmi ascolto.
sentences.translated: But do not listen to me.

sentences.original: E non guardare più quel portale," disse colpendomi lievemente sulla nuca mentre mi rigiravo attirato dalle sculture che avevo visto all'entrata.
sentences.translated: "And don't look at that portal anymore," he said, lightly tapping me on the nape of my neck as I turned around, drawn by the sculptures I had seen at the entrance.

sentences.original: "Per quest'oggi ti hanno spaventato abbastanza.
sentences.translated: For today, they have scared you enough.

sentences.original: Tutti.
sentences.translated: All.

sentences.original:
"

Mentre mi rivoltavo verso l'uscita, vidi davanti a me un altro monaco.
sentences.translated: While I was turning towards the exit, I saw another monk in front of me.

sentences.original: Poteva avere la stessa età di Guglielmo.
sentences.translated: He could have been the same age as William.

sentences.original: Ci sorrise e ci salutò urbanamente.
sentences.translated: He smiled at us and greeted us politely.

sentences.original: Disse che era Severino da Sant'Emmerano, ed era il padre erborista, che aveva cura dei balnea, dell'ospedale, e degli orti, e che si metteva al nostro servizio se avessimo voluto orientarci meglio nel recinto dell'abbazia.
sentences.translated: He said he was Severino from Sant'Emmerano, and he was the herbalist father, who took care of the baths, the hospital, and the gardens, and that he would put himself at our service if we had wanted to better orient ourselves within the abbey's grounds.

sentences.original:
Guglielmo lo ringraziò e disse che aveva già notato, entrando, il bellissimo orto, che gli pareva contenere non solo erbe commestibili, ma anche piante medicinali, per quanto si poteva vedere attraverso la neve.
"D'estate o di primavera, con la varietà delle sue erbe, e ciascuna adornata dei suoi fiori, questo orto canta meglio le lodi del Creatore," disse Severino a mo' di scusa.
sentences.translated:
William thanked him and said that he had already noticed, upon entering, the beautiful garden, which seemed to contain not only edible herbs, but also medicinal plants, as much as could be seen through the snow.

"In summer or spring, with the variety of its herbs, and each adorned with its flowers, this garden sings better the praises of the Creator," said Severino by way of excuse.

sentences.original: "Ma anche in questa stagione l'occhio dell'erborista vede attraverso i rami secchi le piante che verranno e può dirti che quest'orto è più ricco di quanto mai lo fu un erbario, e più variopinto, per quanto bellissime siano le miniature di quello.
sentences.translated: But even in this season the herbalist's eye sees through the bare branches the plants that will come, and can tell you that this garden is richer than any herbarium ever was, and more colorful, however beautiful the miniatures of the latter may be.

sentences.original: E poi anche in inverno crescono le erbe buone, e altre ne tengo raccolte e pronte nei vasi che ho in laboratorio.
sentences.translated: And even in winter, good herbs grow, and I keep others collected and ready in the jars that I have in the laboratory.

sentences.original: Così con le radici dell'acetosella si curano i catarri, e con decotto di radici di althea si fanno impacchi per le malattie della pelle, con la lappa si cicatrizzano gli eczemi, triturando e macinando il rizoma della bistorta si curano le diarree e alcuni mali delle donne, la lippia è un buon digestivo, la farfara va bene per la tosse, e abbiamo della buona genziana per digerire, e della glycyrrhiza, e del ginepro per farne un buon infuso, il sambuco da farne con la corteccia un decotto
sentences.translated: So with the roots of sorrel, catarrh is treated, and with a decoction of marsh-mallow roots, poultices are made for skin diseases, with burdock, eczema is healed, by crushing and grinding the rhizome of bistort, diarrhea and some women's ailments are treated, lippia is a good digestive, coltsfoot is good for coughs, and we have some good gentian for digestion, and some licorice, and some juniper to make a good infusion, elder to make a decoction with the bark.

sentences.original: per
sentences.translated: for

sentences.original: il fegato, la saponaria da macerarne le radici in acqua fredda, per il catarro, e la valeriana di cui certo conoscete le virtù.
sentences.translated: The liver, the soapwort whose roots are to be macerated in cold water, for catarrh, and valerian of which you certainly know the virtues.

sentences.original:
"
"Avete erbe diverse e buone per climi diversi.
sentences.translated: "You have different and good herbs for different climates."

sentences.original: Come mai?
sentences.translated: What's up?

sentences.original:
"
"Per un lato lo devo alla misericordia del Signore, che ha posto il nostro altopiano a cavallo di una catena che vede a meridione il mare, e ne riceve i venti caldi, e a settentrione la montagna più alta di cui riceve i balsami silvestri.
sentences.translated: "On one hand, I owe it to the mercy of the Lord, who has placed our plateau astride a range that sees the sea to the south, from which it receives the warm winds, and to the north the highest mountain from which it receives the silvary balms."

sentences.original: E per un lato lo devo all'abito dell'arte, che ho indegnamente acquisito per volontà dei miei maestri.
sentences.translated: And for one side, I owe it to the habit of the art, which I have unworthily acquired by the will of my masters.

sentences.original: Certe piante crescono anche in clima avverso se ne curi il terreno circostante, e il nutrimento, e la crescita.
sentences.translated: Certain plants also grow in adverse climates if you take care of the surrounding soil, the nourishment, and the growth.

sentences.original:
"
"Ma avete anche piante buone solo per mangiare?" domandai.
"Mio giovane puledro affamato, non ci sono piante buone per il cibo che non siano anche per la cura, purché prese in giusta misura.
sentences.translated:
"But do you also have plants that are good only for eating?" I asked.
"My young, hungry colt, there are no plants good for food that are not also good for healing, as long as they are taken in the right measure."

sentences.original: Solo l'eccesso le rende causa di malattia.
sentences.translated: Only excess makes them a cause of disease.

sentences.original: Prendi la zucca.
sentences.translated: Take the pumpkin.

sentences.original: E' di natura fredda e umida e mitiga la sete, ma a mangiarla guasta ti provoca diarrea e devi restringere le tue viscere con un impasto di salamoia e senape.
sentences.translated: It is of a cold and moist nature and mitigates thirst, but if you eat it, it spoils you and causes diarrhea, and you must constrict your bowels with a poultice of brine and mustard.

sentences.original: E le cipolle?
sentences.translated: And what about the onions?

sentences.original: Calde e umide, poche potenziano il coito, naturalmente per coloro che non han pronunciato i nostri voti, troppe ti dan pesantezza di capo e van combattute con latte e aceto.
sentences.translated: Warm and moist, a few enhance intercourse, naturally for those who have not taken our vows, too many cause heaviness in the head and should be countered with milk and vinegar.

sentences.original: Buona ragione," aggiunse con malizia, "perché un giovane monaco ne mangi sempre con parsimonia.
sentences.translated: "Good reason," he added maliciously, "because a young monk always eats it sparingly."

sentences.original: Mangia invece aglio.
sentences.translated: Eat garlic instead.

sentences.original: Caldo e secco, è buono contro i veleni.
sentences.translated: Hot and dry, it is good against poisons.

sentences.original: Ma non esagerare, fa espellere troppi umori dal cervello.
sentences.translated: But don't overdo it, it causes too many humors to be expelled from the brain.

sentences.original: I fagioli invece producono urina e ingrassano, due cose molto buone.
sentences.translated: The beans, instead, produce urine and make you fat, two very good things.

sentences.original: Ma danno cattivi sogni.
sentences.translated: But they give bad dreams.

sentences.original: Molto meno però di certe altre erbe, perché ve ne sono anche che provocano cattive visioni.
sentences.translated: Much less so than certain other herbs, because there are also some that cause bad visions.

sentences.original:
"
"Quali?" domandai.
"Eh, eh, il nostro novizio vuole sapere troppo.
sentences.translated:
"What ones?" I asked.
"Eh, eh, our novice wants to know too much."

sentences.original: Queste sono cose che deve sapere solo l'erborista, se no qualsiasi sconsiderato potrebbe andare in giro a somministrar visioni, ovvero a mentire con le erbe.
sentences.translated: These are things that only the herbalist should know, otherwise any reckless person could go around administering visions, that is, lying with herbs.

sentences.original:
"
"Ma basta un poco d'urtica," disse allora Guglielmo, "o la roybra, o l'olieribus, e si è protetti contro le visioni.
sentences.translated: "Just a bit of nettle," said Guglielmo then, "or the roybra, or the olieribus, and one is protected against visions."

sentences.original: Spero che voi abbiate di queste buone erbe.
sentences.translated: I hope that you have some of these good herbs.

sentences.original:
"

Severino guardò il maestro di sottecchi:
sentences.translated: Severino looked at the teacher out of the corner of his eye:

sentences.original: "Ti interessi di erboristeria?
sentences.translated: Are you interested in herbalism?

sentences.original:
"
"Molto poco," disse modestamente Guglielmo, "una volta ebbi tra le mani il Theatrum Sanitatis di Ububchasym de Baldach..."
"Abul Asan al Muchtar ibn Botlan.
sentences.translated:
"Very little," said Guglielmo modestly, "once I had in my hands the Theatrum Sanitatis by Ububchasym de Baldach..."
"Abul Asan al Muchtar ibn Botlan."

sentences.original:
"
"O Ellucasim Elimittar, come vuoi tu.
sentences.translated: "O Ellucasim Elimittar, as you wish."

sentences.original: Mi chiedo se se ne potrà trovare una copia qui.
sentences.translated: I wonder if a copy can be found here.

sentences.original:
"
"E delle più belle, con molte immagini di preziosa fattura.
sentences.translated: "And of the most beautiful, with many images of precious craftsmanship."

sentences.original:
"
"Sia lode al cielo.
sentences.translated: "Praise be to heaven."

sentences.original: E il De virtutibus herbarum del Platearius?
sentences.translated: And the De virtutibus herbarum by Platearius?

sentences.original:
"
"Anche quello, e il De plantis e il De vegetalibus di Aristotele tradotto da Alfredo di Sareshel.
sentences.translated: "Also that, and Aristotle's De plantis and De vegetalibus translated by Alfred of Sareshel."

sentences.original:
"
"Ho sentito dire che non sia veramente di Aristotele," osservò Guglielmo, "come non era di Aristotele, si scoprì, il De causis.
sentences.translated: "I've heard it said that it's not truly by Aristotle," observed William, "just as the De causis was not by Aristotle, it turned out."

sentences.original:
"
"In ogni caso è un grande libro," osservò Severino, e il mio maestro ne convenne con molto fervore senza chiedere se l'erborista parlasse del De vegetalibus o del De causis, due opere che non conoscevo ma che da quella conversazione conclusi essere grandissime entrambe.
sentences.translated: "In any case, it's a great book," observed Severino, and my teacher agreed with great enthusiasm without asking if the herbalist was referring to the De vegetalibus or the De causis, two works that I did not know but that from that conversation I concluded were both magnificent.

sentences.original: "Sarò lieto," concluse Severino, "di avere con te qualche onesta conversazione sulle erbe.
sentences.translated: "I will be happy," Severino concluded, "to have with you an honest conversation about herbs."

sentences.original:
"
"Io più di te," disse Guglielmo, "ma non violeremo la regola del silenzio, che mi pare viga nel vostro ordine?
sentences.translated: "I more than you," said William, "but we will not violate the rule of silence, which I believe holds in your order?"

sentences.original:
"
"La regola," disse Severino, "si è adattata nei secoli alle esigenze delle diverse comunità.
sentences.translated: "The rule," said Severino, "has adapted over the centuries to the needs of different communities."

sentences.original: La regola prevedeva la lectio divina ma non lo studio:
sentences.translated: The rule provided for lectio divina but not study:

sentences.original: eppure sai quanto il nostro ordine abbia sviluppato la ricerca sulle cose divine e sulle cose umane.
sentences.translated: And yet you know how much our order has developed the study of divine and human things.

sentences.original: Ancora, la regola prevede il dormitorio comune, ma talora è giusto, come da noi, che i monaci abbiano possibilità di riflessione anche durante la notte, e così ciascuno di essi ha la propria cella.
sentences.translated: Still, the rule provides for a common dormitory, but sometimes it is right, as with us, that the monks have the possibility of reflection even during the night, and so each of them has his own cell.

sentences.original: La regola è molto severa riguardo al silenzio, e anche da noi non solo il monaco che fa opere manuali ma anche colui che scrive o che legge non deve conversare coi suoi fratelli.
sentences.translated: The rule is very strict regarding silence, and even among us, not only the monk who does manual work but also the one who writes or reads must not converse with his brothers.

sentences.original: Ma l'abbazia è anzitutto una comunità di studiosi e spesso è utile che i monaci si scambino i tesori di dottrina che accumulano.
sentences.translated: But the abbey is first and foremost a community of scholars and it is often useful for the monks to exchange the treasures of knowledge that they accumulate.

sentences.original: Ogni conversazione che riguardi i nostri studi è ritenuta legittima e profittevole, purché non si svolga in refettorio o durante le ore degli uffici sacri.
sentences.translated: Every conversation concerning our studies is considered legitimate and profitable, provided it does not take place in the refectory or during the hours of sacred offices.

sentences.original:
"
"Hai avuto occasione di parlare molto con Adelmo da Otranto?
sentences.translated: "Have you had the opportunity to talk much with Adelmo from Otranto?"

sentences.original: " chiese bruscamente Guglielmo.
sentences.translated: "asked abruptly William."

sentences.original: Severino non parve sorpreso:
sentences.translated: Severino did not seem surprised:

sentences.original: "Vedo che l'Abate ti ha già parlato," disse.
sentences.translated: "I see that the Abbot has already spoken to you," he said.

sentences.original: "No.
sentences.translated: No.

sentences.original: Con lui non mi intrattenevo sovente.
sentences.translated: With him, I did not often converse.

sentences.original: Passava il tempo a miniare.
sentences.translated: He spent his time illuminating manuscripts.

sentences.original: L'ho udito talora discutere con altri monaci, Venanzio da Salvemec, o Jorge da Burgos, sulla natura del suo lavoro.
sentences.translated: I have sometimes heard him discussing with other monks, Venantius of Salvemec, or Jorge of Burgos, about the nature of his work.

sentences.original:
E poi io non passo la giornata nello scriptorium, ma nel mio laboratorio," e accennò all'edificio dell'ospedale.
"Capisco," disse Guglielmo.
sentences.translated:
"And then I do not spend the day in the scriptorium, but in my laboratory," and he gestured towards the hospital building.
"I see," said William.

sentences.original: "Dunque non sai se Adelmo avesse avuto visioni.
sentences.translated: So you don't know if Adelmo had visions.

sentences.translated: Severino stiffened:

sentences.translated: I said that I keep the dangerous herbs with great care.

"Non dico questo," si affrettò a precisare Guglielmo.
sentences.translated: " "I don't mean that," Guglielmo hastened to clarify.

sentences.original: "Parlavo di visioni in genere.
sentences.translated: I was talking about visions in general.

"
"Non capisco," insisté Severino.
sentences.translated: "I don't understand," insisted Severino.

sentences.original: "Pensavo che un monaco che si aggira di notte per l'Edificio, dove per ammissione dell'Abate possono accadere cose... tremende a chi vi entri in ore proibite, bene, dicevo, pensavo che potesse aver avuto visioni diaboliche che l'avessero spinto nel precipizio.
sentences.translated: I thought that a monk who wanders at night in the Building, where, by the Abbot's own admission, terrible things can happen to those who enter at forbidden hours, well, I was saying, I thought that he might have had diabolical visions that drove him over the precipice.

sentences.original:
"
"Ho detto che non frequento lo scriptorium, salvo quando mi serve qualche libro, ma di solito ho i miei erbari che conservo nell'ospedale.
sentences.translated: "I said that I do not frequent the scriptorium, except when I need some book, but usually I have my herbals that I keep in the hospital."

sentences.original: Ti ho detto, Adelmo era molto familiare di Jorge, di Venanzio e... naturalmente, di Berengario.
sentences.translated: I told you, Adelmo was very familiar with Jorge, with Venanzio and... naturally, with Berengario.

"

Avvertii anch'io una lieve esitazione nella voce di Severino.
sentences.translated: "I also noticed a slight hesitation in Severino's voice."

sentences.original: Né sfuggì al mio maestro:
sentences.translated: Nor did it escape my teacher:

sentences.original: "Berengario?
sentences.translated: "Berengar?"

sentences.translated: And why naturally?
