sentences.translated: And then that evening I saw Berengario and Adelmo conferring in the cloister, before going to the refectory.

"

sentences.translated: "You know that the two people who recently died under mysterious circumstances had asked something of Berengar," said William.

sentences.original: Bencio rispose a disagio:
sentences.translated: Bencio replied uncomfortably:

sentences.original: "Non ho detto questo!
sentences.translated: I did not say that!

sentences.original: Ho detto quello che è avvenuto quel giorno e come voi mi avete chiesto..." Rifletté un poco, poi aggiunse in fretta:
sentences.translated: I said what happened that day and as you asked me..." He reflected for a moment, then added quickly:

sentences.original: "Ma se volete sapere la mia opinione, Berengario ha parlato loro di qualcosa che sta in biblioteca, ed è là che dovreste cercare.
sentences.translated: But if you want to know my opinion, Berengar spoke to them about something that is in the library, and that is where you should look.

sentences.original:
"
"Perché pensi alla biblioteca?
sentences.translated: Why do you think about the library?

sentences.original: Cosa voleva dire Berengario con le parole cercare tra gli africani?
sentences.translated: What did Berengar mean with the words "to search among the Africans"?

sentences.original: Non voleva dire che bisognava leggere meglio i poeti africani?
sentences.translated: Didn't you say we should read African poets more closely?

sentences.original:
"
"Forse, così pareva, ma allora perché Malachia avrebbe dovuto infuriarsi?
sentences.translated: "Perhaps, it seemed so, but then why would Malachia have had to get angry?"

sentences.original: In fondo dipende da lui decidere se deve dare in lettura un libro di poeti africani, o no.
sentences.translated: In the end, it depends on him to decide whether he should give a book of African poets to be read, or not.

sentences.original: Ma io so una cosa:
sentences.translated: But I know one thing:

sentences.translated: Whoever browses the book catalog will find, among the indications that only the librarian knows, one that often says "Africa" and I even found one that said "finis Africae".

sentences.original: Una volta chiesi un libro che recava quel segno, non ricordo quale, il titolo mi aveva incuriosito;
sentences.translated: Once I asked for a book that bore that mark, I don't remember which, the title had intrigued me;

sentences.original: e Malachia mi disse che i libri con quel segno erano andati perduti.
sentences.translated: and Malachi told me that the books with that sign had been lost.

sentences.original: Ecco quello che so.

sentences.translated: For this reason I tell you:

sentences.translated: It's right, check Berengario, and check him when he goes up to the library.

"

sentences.translated: "One never knows," concluded William as he took his leave.

sentences.translated: First of all, once again, Berengar was the subject of the murmurs of his fellow monks.

sentences.original: in secondo luogo
sentences.translated: In second place

sentences.translated: Bencio seemed eager to push us towards the library.

sentences.original: Osservai che forse voleva che noi scoprissimo laggiù cose che anche lui voleva sapere e Guglielmo disse che probabilmente era così, ma che poteva anche darsi che spingendoci verso la biblioteca volesse allontanarci da qualche altro luogo.
sentences.translated: I observed that perhaps he wanted us to discover things down there that he also wanted to know, and William said that it was probably so, but that it could also be that by pushing us towards the library he wanted to move us away from some other place.

sentences.original: Quale?
sentences.translated: Which?

sentences.original: , domandai.

sentences.translated: And William said that he did not know, perhaps the scriptorium, perhaps the kitchen, or the choir, or the dormitory, or the hospital.

sentences.original: Osservai che il giorno prima era lui, Guglielmo, a essere affascinato dalla biblioteca ed egli rispose che voleva essere affascinato dalle cose che piacevano a lui e non da quelle che gli altri gli consigliavano.
sentences.translated: I noticed that the day before it was he, William, who was fascinated by the library, and he replied that he wanted to be fascinated by things that he liked and not by those that others advised him to.

sentences.original: Che però la biblioteca andava tenuta d'occhio, e che a quel punto non sarebbe stato male neppure cercare di penetrarvi in qualche modo.
sentences.translated: That however the library needed to be kept an eye on, and that at that point it wouldn't have been bad to even try to penetrate it in some way.

sentences.original: Le circostanze ormai lo autorizzavano a essere curioso ai limiti della cortesia e del rispetto per gli usi e le leggi dell'abbazia.
sentences.translated: The circumstances now authorized him to be curious to the point of being impolite and disrespectful of the customs and laws of the abbey.

sentences.original: Ci stavamo allontanando dal chiostro.
sentences.translated: We were moving away from the cloister.

sentences.original: Servi e novizi stavano uscendo dalla chiesa dopo la messa.
sentences.translated: Servants and novices were leaving the church after mass.

sentences.original: E mentre doppiavamo il lato occidentale del tempio scorgemmo Berengario che usciva dal portale del transetto e attraversava il cimitero verso l'Edificio.
sentences.translated: And as we rounded the western side of the temple, we spotted Berengario coming out of the transept portal and crossing the cemetery towards the Building.

sentences.original: Guglielmo lo chiamò, quello si arrestò e lo raggiungemmo.
sentences.translated: William called him, he stopped, and we caught up with him.

sentences.original: Era ancora più sconvolto di quando lo avevamo visto in coro e Guglielmo decise evidentemente di approfittare, come aveva fatto con Bencio, del suo stato d'animo.
sentences.translated: It was even more upset than when we had seen him in the choir, and William evidently decided to take advantage, as he had done with Bencio, of his state of mind.

sentences.original: "Dunque pare che tu sia stato l'ultimo a vedere Adelmo vivo," gli disse.
sentences.translated: "Well, it seems that you were the last to see Adelmo alive," he told him.

sentences.original: Berengario vacillò come stesse per cadere in deliquio:
sentences.translated: Berengario wavered as if he were about to faint:

sentences.original: "Io?" comandò con un filo di voce.
sentences.translated: "Me?" he commanded in a faint voice.

sentences.original: Guglielmo aveva buttato la sua domanda quasi a caso, probabilmente perché Bencio gli aveva detto di avere visto i due confabulare nel chiostro dopo vespro.
sentences.translated: William had thrown out his question almost at random, probably because Bence had told him that he had seen the two conferring in the cloister after vespers.

sentences.original: Ma doveva avere colto nel segno e Berengario stava chiaramente pensando a un altro e veramente ultimo incontro, perché cominciò a parlare con voce rotta.
sentences.translated: But he must have hit the mark and Berengar was clearly thinking of another and truly final meeting, because he began to speak with a broken voice.

sentences.original: "Come potete dire questo, io l'ho visto prima di andare a riposare come tutti gli altri!
sentences.translated: How can you say this, I saw it before going to rest like everyone else!

sentences.original:
"

Allora Guglielmo decise che valeva la pena di non dargli respiro:
sentences.translated: "Then William decided that it was worth not giving him a break:"

sentences.original: "No, tu l'hai visto ancora e sai più cose di quanto non voglia far credere.
sentences.translated: No, you have seen it again and you know more than you want to let on.

sentences.original: Ma qui sono in gioco ormai due morti e non puoi più tacere.
sentences.translated: But now two deaths are at stake and you can no longer remain silent.

sentences.original: Sai benissimo che vi sono molti modi per far parlare una persona!
sentences.translated: You know very well that there are many ways to make a person talk!

sentences.original:
"

Guglielmo mi aveva detto più volte che, anche da inquisitore, aveva sempre rifuggito dalla tortura, ma Berengario lo fraintese (o Guglielmo voleva farsi fraintendere), in ogni caso il suo gioco risultò efficace.
sentences.translated: William had told me more than once that, even as an inquisitor, he had always shunned torture, but Berengar misunderstood him (or William wanted to be misunderstood). In any case, his ploy was effective.

sentences.original:
"Sì, sì," disse Berengario rompendo in un pianto dirotto, "io ho visto Adelmo quella sera, ma lo vidi già morto!"
"Come?" interrogò Guglielmo, "ai piedi della scarpata?
sentences.translated:
"Yes, yes," said Berengar, bursting into a flood of tears, "I saw Adelmo that evening, but I saw him already dead!"
"How?" inquired William, "at the foot of the cliff?"

sentences.original:
"
"No, no, lo vidi qui nel cimitero, procedeva tra le tombe, larva tra le larve.
sentences.translated: "No, no, I saw him here in the cemetery, moving among the graves, a ghost among ghosts.

sentences.original: Lo incontrai e subito mi accorsi che non avevo di fronte a me un vivo, il suo volto era quello di un cadavere, i suoi occhi guardavano già le pene eterne.
sentences.translated: I met him and immediately realized that I did not have a living person in front of me, his face was that of a corpse, his eyes were already looking at eternal punishments.

sentences.original: Naturalmente solo il mattino dopo, apprendendo della sua morte, io capii che ne avevo incontrato il fantasma, ma già in quel momento mi resi conto che stavo avendo una visione e che davanti a me stava un'anima dannata, un lemure... Oh Signore, con quale voce di tomba mi parlò!
sentences.translated: Naturally, it was only the next morning, upon learning of his death, that I realized I had encountered his ghost, but even at that moment I realized that I was having a vision and that before me stood a damned soul, a lemure... Oh Lord, with what a tomb-like voice he spoke to me!

sentences.original:
"
"E che disse?
sentences.translated: "And what did he say?"

sentences.original: "«Sono dannato!» così mi disse.
sentences.translated: «I am damned!» he said to me.

sentences.original: «Tal quale mi vedi hai di fronte a te un reduce dall'inferno e all'inferno bisogna che torni.
sentences.translated: Just as you see me, you have before you a survivor of hell and to hell I must return.

sentences.original: » Così mi disse.
sentences.translated: "Thus he told me."

sentences.original: E io gli gridai:
sentences.translated: And I shouted to him:

sentences.original: «Adelmo, vieni davvero dall'inferno?
sentences.translated: Adelmo, do you really come from hell?

sentences.original: Come sono le pene dell'inferno?» E tremavo, perché da poco ero uscito dall'ufficio di compieta dove avevo udito leggere pagine tremende sull'ira del Signore.
sentences.translated: "How are the pains of hell?" And I trembled, because I had just come out of the office of Compline where I had heard pages read that were dreadful about the wrath of the Lord.

sentences.original: Ed egli mi disse:
sentences.translated: And he said to me:

sentences.original: «Le pene dell'inferno sono infinitamente maggiori di quanto la nostra lingua possa dire.
sentences.translated: The pains of hell are infinitely greater than what our language can express.

sentences.original: Vedi tu,» disse, «questa cappa di sofismi della quale sono stato vestito sino a oggi?
sentences.translated: See for yourself," he said, "this cloak of sophisms with which I have been dressed until today?"

sentences.original: Questa mi grava e pesa come avessi la maggior torre di Parigi o la montagna del mondo in su le spalle e mai la potrò più porre giù.
sentences.translated: This weighs heavily on me and it presses like I had the tallest tower of Paris or the mountain of the world on my shoulders and I will never be able to put it down again.

sentences.original: E questa pena m'è stata data dalla divina giustizia per la mia vanagloria, per aver creduto il mio corpo un luogo di delizie, e per l'aver supposto di sapere più degli altri, e per l'essermi dilettato di cose mostruose, che vagheggiate nella mia immaginazione hanno prodotto cose ben più mostruose nell'interno dell'anima mia - e ora con esse dovrò vivere in eterno.
sentences.translated: And this punishment has been given to me by divine justice for my vanity, for having believed my body to be a place of delights, and for having supposed that I knew more than others, and for having delighted in monstrous things, which, imagined in my mind, have produced even more monstrous things within my soul - and now I shall have to live with them forever.

sentences.original: Vedi tu?
sentences.translated: Do you see?

sentences.original: Il fodero di questa cappa è come fosse tutto bracia e fuoco ardente, ed è il fuoco che arde il mio corpo, e questa pena m'è data per il peccato disonesto della carne, della quale mi viziai, e questo fuoco ora senza sosta mi divampa e mi arde!
sentences.translated: The sheath of this cloak is as if it were all burning coals and blazing fire, and it is the fire that burns my body, and this torment is given to me for the dishonest sin of the flesh, which I indulged in, and this fire now without ceasing blazes and burns me!

sentences.original: Porgimi la tua mano, mio bel maestro,» mi disse ancora, «affinché il mio incontro ti sia di utile ammaestramento, rendendoti in cambio molti degli ammaestramenti che mi desti, porgimi la tua mano mio bel maestro!» E scosse il dito della sua mano che ardeva, e mi cadde sulla mano una piccola goccia del suo sudore e mi parve che mi forasse la mano, che per molti giorni ne portai il segno, solo che lo nascosi a tutti.
sentences.translated: "Give me your hand, my dear teacher," he said to me again, "so that my encounter may be of useful instruction to you, giving you in exchange many of the instructions that you gave me. Give me your hand, my dear teacher!" And he shook the finger of his hand that was burning, and a small drop of his sweat fell on my hand, and it seemed to me that it bored a hole in my hand, which for many days I bore the mark, except that I hid it from everyone.

sentences.original: Poi scomparve tra le tombe, e il mattino dopo seppi che quel corpo, che mi aveva così atterrito, stava già morto ai piedi della rocca.
sentences.translated: Then he vanished among the tombs, and the next morning I learned that the body, which had so terrified me, was already dead at the foot of the cliff.

"

Berengario ansimava, e piangeva.
sentences.translated: Berengar was panting, and crying.

sentences.original: Guglielmo gli domandò:
sentences.translated: William asked him:

sentences.original: "E come mai ti chiamava suo bel maestro?
sentences.translated: And why did she call you her handsome teacher?

sentences.original: Avevate la stessa età.
sentences.translated: You were the same age.

sentences.original: Gli avevi forse insegnato qualcosa?
sentences.translated: Had you perhaps taught him something?

sentences.original:
"

Berengario nascose il capo tirandosi il cappuccio sul volto, e cadde in ginocchio abbracciando le gambe di Guglielmo:
sentences.translated: Berengario hid his face by pulling his hood over his face, and he fell to his knees, embracing Guglielmo's legs:

sentences.original: "Non so, non so perché mi chiamasse così, io non gli ho insegnato nulla!" e scoppiò in singhiozzi.
sentences.translated: "I don't know, I don't know why he called me that, I didn't teach him anything!" and she burst into sobs.

sentences.original:
"Ho paura, padre, voglio confessarmi da voi, misericordia, un diavolo mi mangia le viscere!"

Guglielmo lo scostò da sé e gli porse la mano per rialzarlo.
sentences.translated:
"I am afraid, father, I want to confess to you, mercy, a devil is eating my entrails!"

Guglielmo pushed him away and offered him his hand to help him up.

sentences.original: "No Berengario," gli disse, "non chiedermi di confessarti.
sentences.translated: "No Berengar," he said to him, "do not ask me to confess you."

sentences.original: Non chiudere le mie labbra aprendo le tue.
sentences.translated: Don't close my lips by opening yours.

sentences.original: Quello che voglio sapere di te me lo dirai in altro modo.
sentences.translated: What I want to know about you, you will tell me in another way.

sentences.original: E se non me lo dirai lo scoprirò per conto mio.
sentences.translated: And if you won't tell me, I'll find out for myself.

sentences.original: Chiedimi misericordia, se vuoi, non chiedermi il silenzio.
sentences.translated: Ask me for mercy, if you want, don't ask me for silence.

sentences.original: Troppi tacciono in questa abbazia.
sentences.translated: Too many are silent in this abbey.

sentences.original: Dimmi piuttosto, come hai visto il suo volto pallido se era notte fonda, come ha potuto bruciarti la mano se era notte di pioggia e di grandine e di nevischio, cosa facevi nel cimitero?
sentences.translated: Tell me rather, how did you see his pale face if it was the dead of night, how could it burn your hand if it was a night of rain and hail and sleet, what were you doing in the cemetery?

sentences.original:
Avanti," e lo scosse con brutalità per le spalle, "dimmi almeno questo!"

Berengario tremava in tutte le sue membra:
sentences.translated:
"Come on," and he shook him brutally by the shoulders, "at least tell me this!"

Berengario was trembling in every limb:

sentences.original: "Non so cosa facessi nel cimitero, non ricordo.
sentences.translated: "I don't know what I was doing in the cemetery, I don't remember."

sentences.original:
Non so perché ho visto il suo volto, forse avevo una luce, no... lui aveva una luce, portava un lume, forse ho visto il suo volto alla luce della fiamma..."
"Come poteva portare una luce se pioveva e nevicava?
sentences.translated:
I don't know why I saw his face, maybe I had a light, no... he had a light, he was carrying a lantern, maybe I saw his face in the light of the flame..."
"How could he carry a light if it was raining and snowing?"

"
"Era dopo compieta, subito dopo compieta, non nevicava ancora, ha cominciato dopo...
sentences.translated: "It was after Compline, right after Compline, it wasn't snowing yet, it started after..."

sentences.translated: I was fleeing towards the dormitory.

sentences.translated: I was fleeing towards the dormitory, in the opposite direction from where the ghost was going... And then I don't know anything else, please, don't ask me any more questions, unless you want to confess to me.

"

sentences.translated: "All right," said William, "now go, go to the choir, go and speak with the Lord, since you do not want to speak with men, or go and find a monk who will listen to your confession, because if from then on you do not confess your sins, you have approached the sacraments as a sacrilegious person."

sentences.original: Vai.
sentences.translated: Go.

sentences.original: Ci rivedremo.
sentences.translated: We will see each other again.

"

Berengario scomparve di corsa.
sentences.translated: Berengario disappeared in a hurry.

sentences.original: E Guglielmo si sfregò le mani come lo avevo visto fare in molti altri casi in cui era soddisfatto di qualcosa.
sentences.translated: And William rubbed his hands together as I had seen him do in many other cases where he was satisfied with something.

sentences.original: "Bene," disse, "ora molte cose diventano chiare.
sentences.translated: "Well," he said, "now many things become clear."

sentences.original:
"
"Chiare, maestro?
sentences.translated: "Clear, master?"

sentences.original: " gli domandai, "chiare ora che abbiamo anche il fantasma di Adelmo?
sentences.translated: I asked him, "Is it clear now that we also have Adelmo's ghost?"

sentences.original:
"
"Caro Adso," disse Guglielmo, "quel fantasma mi pare pochissimo fantasma e in ogni caso recitava una pagina che ho già letto su qualche libro a uso dei predicatori.
sentences.translated: "Dear Adso," said William, "that ghost seems to me very little like a ghost, and in any case, it was reciting a page that I have already read in some book for the use of preachers."

sentences.original: Questi monaci leggono forse troppo, e quando sono eccitati rivivono le visioni che ebbero sui libri.
sentences.translated: These monks perhaps read too much, and when they are excited they relive the visions they had from the books.

sentences.original: Non so se Adelmo abbia detto davvero quelle cose o se Berengario le abbia udite perché aveva bisogno di udirle.
sentences.translated: I don't know if Adelmo really said those things or if Berengar heard them because he needed to hear them.

sentences.original: E' un fatto che questa storia conferma una serie di mie supposizioni.
sentences.translated: It's a fact that this story confirms a series of my assumptions.

sentences.original: Per esempio: Adelmo è morto suicida, e la storia di Berengario ci dice che, prima di morire, girava in preda a una grande eccitazione, e rimorso per qualcosa che aveva commesso.
sentences.translated: For example: Adelmo died by suicide, and the story of Berengar tells us that, before dying, he was in a state of great excitement and remorse for something he had done.

sentences.original: Era eccitato e spaventato per il suo peccato perché qualcuno lo aveva spaventato, e forse gli aveva raccontato proprio l'episodio dell'apparizione infernale che egli ha recitato a Berengario con tanta e allucinata maestria.
sentences.translated: He was excited and frightened by his sin because someone had frightened him, and perhaps had told him precisely the episode of the infernal apparition that he had performed for Berengar with such and hallucinated mastery.

sentences.original: E passava dal cimitero perché veniva dal coro, dove si era confidato (o confessato) con qualcuno che gli aveva incusso terrore e rimorso.
sentences.translated: And he was passing by the cemetery because he had come from the choir, where he had confided in (or confessed to) someone who had instilled in him terror and remorse.

sentences.original: E dal cimitero si avviava, come ci ha fatto comprendere Berengario, in direzione opposta al dormitorio.
sentences.translated: And from the cemetery, as Berengar has made us understand, it headed in the opposite direction to the dormitory.

sentences.original: Verso l'Edificio, dunque, ma anche (è possibile) verso il muro di cinta dietro gli stabbi, da dove ho dedotto debba essersi gettato nel dirupo.
sentences.translated: Toward the Building, then, but also (it is possible) toward the perimeter wall behind the stables, from where I deduced he must have thrown himself into the ravine.

sentences.original: E si è gettato prima che sopravvenisse la tempesta, è morto ai piedi del muro, e solo dopo la frana ha portato il suo cadavere tra la torre settentrionale e quella orientale.
sentences.translated: And he threw himself before the storm came, he died at the foot of the wall, and only after the landslide carried his body between the northern tower and the eastern one.

"Ma la goccia di sudore infuocato?
sentences.translated: "But the drop of burning sweat?"

"Stava già nella storia che lui ha udito e ha ripetuto, o che Berengario si è figurata nella sua eccitazione e nel suo rimorso.
sentences.translated: "It was already in the story that he had heard and repeated, or that Berengario had imagined in her excitement and her remorse."

sentences.original: Perché vi è, in antistrofe al rimorso di Adelmo, un rimorso di Berengario, lo hai sentito.
sentences.translated: Because, in contrast to Adelmo's remorse, there is Berengar's remorse, you have heard it.

sentences.original: E se Adelmo veniva dal coro portava forse un cero, e la goccia sulla mano dell'amico era solo una goccia di cera.
sentences.translated: And if Adelmo came from the choir, he might have been carrying a candle, and the drop on his friend's hand was just a drop of wax.

sentences.original: Ma Berengario si è sentito bruciare molto di più perché Adelmo certamente lo ha chiamato suo maestro.
sentences.translated: But Berengario felt much more burned because Adelmo certainly called him his master.

sentences.original: Segno dunque che Adelmo lo rimproverava di avergli appreso qualcosa di cui ora egli si disperava a morte.
sentences.translated: I thus signify that Adelmo reproached him for having taught him something about which he now despaired to death.

sentences.original: E Berengario lo sa, egli soffre perché sa di avere spinto Adelmo alla morte facendogli fare qualcosa che non doveva.
sentences.translated: And Berengar knows it, he suffers because he knows he pushed Adelmo to his death by making him do something he shouldn't have.

sentences.original: E non è difficile immaginare cosa, mio povero Adso, dopo quello che abbiamo udito sul nostro aiuto bibliotecario.
sentences.translated: And it is not difficult to imagine what, my poor Adso, after what we have heard about our assistant librarian.

sentences.original:
"
"Credo di aver capito cosa è accaduto tra i due," dissi vergognandomi della mia sagacia, "ma non crediamo tutti in un Dio di misericordia?
sentences.translated: "I think I've figured out what happened between the two of them," I said, ashamed of my own insight, "but don't we all believe in a merciful God?"

sentences.original: Adelmo, dite, si era probabilmente confessato:
sentences.translated: Adelmo, tell me, he had probably confessed:

sentences.original: perché ha cercato di punire il suo primo peccato con un peccato certo più grande ancora, o almeno di pari gravità?
sentences.translated: Why did he try to punish his first sin with a sin that was certainly even greater, or at least of equal gravity?

sentences.original: "Perché qualcuno gli ha detto parole di disperazione.
sentences.translated: Because someone told him words of despair.

sentences.original: Ho detto che qualche pagina di predicatore dei giorni nostri deve avere suggerito a qualcuno le parole che hanno spaventato Adelmo e con cui Adelmo ha spaventato Berengario.
sentences.translated: I said that some page of a modern-day preacher must have suggested to someone the words that frightened Adelmo and with which Adelmo frightened Berengar.

sentences.original: Mai come in questi ultimi anni i predicatori hanno offerto al popolo, per stimolarne la pietà e il terrore (e il fervore, e l'ossequio alla legge umana e divina), parole truculente, sconvolgenti e macabre.
sentences.translated: Never, as in these last years, have preachers offered to the people, to stimulate their piety and terror (and fervor, and obedience to human and divine law), words that are brutal, shocking, and macabre.

sentences.original: Mai come ai nostri giorni, in mezzo a processioni di flagellanti, si sono udite laudi sacre ispirate ai dolori di Cristo e della Vergine, mai come oggi si è insistito nello stimolare la fede dei semplici attraverso l'evocazione dei tormenti infernali.
sentences.translated: Never, as in our days, amidst processions of flagellants, have sacred hymns inspired by the sufferings of Christ and the Virgin been heard, never as today has there been such insistence on stimulating the faith of the simple through the evocation of infernal torments.

sentences.original:
"
"Forse è bisogno di penitenza," dissi.
"Adso, non ho mai udito tanti richiami alla penitenza quanto oggi, in un periodo in cui ormai né predicatori né vescovi, e neppure i miei confratelli spirituali sono più in grado di promuovere una vera penitenza..."
"Ma la terza età, il papa angelico, il capitolo di Perugia..." dissi smarrito.
"Nostalgie.
sentences.translated:
"Perhaps it is a matter of penance," I said.
"Adso, I have never heard so many calls for penance as today, in a time when neither preachers nor bishops, and not even my spiritual brethren, are able to promote true penance..."
"But the third age, the angelic pope, the chapter of Perugia..." I said, bewildered.
"Nostalgia."

sentences.original: La grande epoca della penitenza è finita, e per questo può parlare di penitenza anche il capitolo generale dell'ordine.
sentences.translated: The great era of penance is over, and for this reason, even the general chapter of the order can speak of penance.

sentences.original: C'è stata, cento, duecento anni fa, una grande ventata di rinnovamento.
sentences.translated: There was, a hundred, two hundred years ago, a great gust of renewal.

sentences.original: C'era quando chi ne parlava veniva bruciato, santo o eretico che fosse.
sentences.translated: There was a time when those who spoke of it were burned, whether they were saint or heretic.

sentences.original: Ora ne parlano tutti.
sentences.translated: Now everyone is talking about it.

sentences.original: In un certo senso ne discute persino il papa.
sentences.translated: In a certain sense, even the pope discusses it.

sentences.original: Non fidarti dei rinnovamenti del genere umano quando ne parlano le curie e le corti.
sentences.translated: Do not trust in the regeneration of mankind when spoken of by the curiae and the courts.

sentences.original:
"
"Ma fra Dolcino," osai, curioso di sapere di più su quel nome che avevo sentito pronunciare più volte il giorno innanzi.
sentences.translated: "But Brother Dolcino," I dared, curious to know more about that name which I had heard pronounced several times the day before.

sentences.original: "E' morto, e malamente come è vissuto, perché anche lui è venuto troppo tardi.
sentences.translated: He's dead, and he died as badly as he lived, because he too came too late.

sentences.original: E poi che ne sai tu?
sentences.translated: And what do you know about it?

sentences.original:
"
"Nulla, per questo vi domando..."
"Preferirei non parlarne mai.
sentences.translated:
"Nothing, that's why I ask you..."
"I would prefer never to speak of it."

sentences.original: Ho avuto a che fare con alcuni dei cosiddetti apostoli, e li ho osservati da vicino.
sentences.translated: I have had to deal with some of the so-called apostles, and I have observed them closely.

sentences.original: Una storia triste.
sentences.translated: A sad story.

sentences.original: Ti turberebbe.
sentences.translated: It would bother you.

sentences.original: In ogni caso ha turbato me, e ancor più ti turberebbe la mia stessa incapacità di giudicare.
sentences.translated: In any case, it has disturbed me, and even more, it would disturb you, my very own inability to judge.

sentences.original: E' la storia di un uomo che fece cose dissennate perché aveva messo in pratica ciò che gli avevano predicato molti santi.
sentences.translated: It's the story of a man who did foolish things because he had put into practice what many saints had preached to him.

sentences.original: A un certo punto non ho più capito di chi fosse la colpa, sono stato come... come obnubilato da un'aria di famiglia che spirava nei due campi avversi, dei santi che predicavano la penitenza e dei peccatori che la mettevano in pratica, spesso a spese degli altri... Ma stavo parlando d'altro.
sentences.translated: At a certain point, I no longer understood whose fault it was. I was like... like I was clouded by a family-like atmosphere that blew through the two opposing sides, of saints preaching penance and sinners putting it into practice, often at the expense of others... But I was talking about something else.

sentences.original: O forse no, parlavo sempre di questo:
sentences.translated: Or maybe not, I always talked about this:

sentences.original: finita l'epoca della penitenza, per i penitenti il bisogno di penitenza è divenuto bisogno di morte.
sentences.translated: Finished the era of penance, for the penitents the need for penance has become a need for death.

sentences.original: E coloro che hanno ucciso i penitenti impazziti, restituendo morte alla morte, per sconfiggere la vera penitenza, che produceva morte, hanno sostituito alla penitenza dell'anima una penitenza dell'immaginazione, un richiamo a visioni soprannaturali di sofferenza e di sangue, chiamandole «specchio» della vera penitenza.
sentences.translated: And those who killed the mad penitents, returning death to death, to defeat true penance, which produced death, replaced the penance of the soul with a penance of the imagination, a call to supernatural visions of suffering and blood, calling them the "mirror" of true penance.

sentences.original: Uno specchio che fa vivere in vita, all'immaginazione dei semplici, e talora anche dei dotti, i tormenti dell'inferno.
sentences.translated: A mirror that brings to life, to the imagination of the simple and sometimes even the learned, the torments of hell.

sentences.original: Affinché - si dice - nessuno pecchi.
sentences.translated: So that - it is said - no one may sin.

sentences.original: Sperando di trattenere le anime dal peccato per mezzo della paura, e confidando di sostituire la paura alla ribellione.
sentences.translated: Hoping to restrain souls from sin through fear, and trusting to replace rebellion with fear.

sentences.translated: "But will they really not sin?" I asked anxiously.
